Saudi holdings of U.S. government bonds climbed to a one-year high of $114.4 billion in March from a low of $89.4 billion last September, the most recent data from the U.S. Treasury Department shows. Compared to 12 months ago, the Saudi holdings were almost unchanged.

The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is currently in an odd position internally.  The actual cost of extracting 1 barrel of oil from the ground is the cheapest in the world at around $8 per barrel.  The major issue for Saudi Arabia is financially supporting the extended royal family.  The House of Saud has essentially created a bourgeoisie that must be supported to maintain power.  Earlier this year the Saudis sold a large dollar amount of bonds of their state run oil company.  That action was very polite to the US, because divesting any noticeable amount of US Treasury Securities would create a decrease in consumer confidence, as well as unnecessarily disrupt the world economy.  In my opinion, The Saudis selling nearly $50 billion of US Treasury Securities would be a declaration of war.

This is mere political saber rattling. Saudi Arabia's currency is not nearly as stable as US currency, therefore they are happy to maintain funds in US Treasury holdings at a premium to retain the value of their money.

Saudi Arabia's treasury holdings stood at $100 billion in November 2016. In Feb 2016, when oil price hit a record (10 year, less than $30/barrel) low, the holdings were $119.9 billion. They have managed to take the worst and the financial situation has improved since (oil is over $50/barrel). From a purely financial standpoint, it seems unlikely that Saudis will need to draw down their reserve.  Why the 5% chance for possible? 
1. Cutting down US treasury holdings has to be a political decision, not economic. 
2. Cutting down US treasury holdings can be seen as a disapproval of the US President/his policies. If you do that to Trump, you can expect a very public backlash. I don't think Saudi regime wants that kind of publicity. 
3. They still need US to guarantee security, especially now that Iran is off sanctions, assertive and on a roll (in Syria, Yemen and Iraq). So they will not want to rub the US government the wrong way.  If the Treasury balance changes dramatically for the worse over the next few months, this opinion will have to be revisited.  Nevertheless, this opinion is formed on basis on very limited information and perceptions. I am unaware of the detailed working of the Saudi economy or the thought process of the regime. I have sufficient confidence in my view to bet a small sum (say $100) but not more.

Changed my mind on this one -reducing my forecast to 1%.  Saudi's holdings are currently $100bn - I can see two reasons to get to $50bn in 5 months:
1) Politically they want to - Trump's America First might not help the relationship, but Saudi probably doesn't want to do anything to distract his attention to themselves away from backing out of the Iran deal. Low probability - 1%?
2) Financially they have to because
2a) They have a deficit of sufficient size that must be financed
2b) This is the best source (ie Can't get money elsewhere)
 Price levels in 2015 caused a $98bn deficit according to ibtimes http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/saudi-arabia-seeking-8bn-loan-plug-fiscal-deficit-1548606 - so to need $50bn in 5 months would need prices below 2015, which I see as possible- we're in the zone of 2015 prices at the moment http://www.marketwatch.com/story/opec-led-bounce-for-oil-prices-starts-to-dissolve-2016-12-05 and I think the oil price could go down over the next few months as I expect Iran to boost supply on concerns that Trump might bring in sanctions against them. I expect US producers to have more favourable conditions as well. so 2a = 60% chance of >$50bn requirement
However, they have $200bn of reserves, so if they take proportionately to fund a deficit, would need $100bn funding requirement in 5 months - which looks unlikely (<10%, maybe way <10%). http://www.tradingeconomics.com/saudi-arabia/foreign-exchange-reserves. Added to which they have issued some bonds, so would need more than $100bn of requirement - just not likely <1%
Overall option 2 = 0% chance

At current rates of sell off - they could be there by February. Not only does the House of Saud need the money to fund its deficit, but also Trump's America First stance probably makes US Treasuries less politically acceptable holdings - hence China's sell-off as well. http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2016-11-16/saudis-china-dump-treasuries-foreign-central-banks-liquidate-record-375-billion-us-p

It does seem to be happy times for the Kingdom,  the oil price continues its robust price base and the economies around the planet seem at least stabilized. So they have an excellent chance to end with a good ratio of reserves, and stay above ~$62B for the period in question.

Based on the new ticdata info, which reveals that USD reserves fell only $2.1 billion in the month of October, it is increasingly unlikely that Saudi Arabia will be burn through 49bn in the 7 months through June. This would require a burn rate of $7 billion/month, unprecedented in modern Saudi history. However, for those who think it is impossible, I'd point out a precedent in late 1990s Asia. Certain Asian economies, notably South Korea and Indonesia, tried to protect their currency for sliding by buying currency with their foreign currency reserves. South Korea burnt through about 45% of their foreign currency between 1996-1997, roughly the same proportion required by Saudi Arabia to get to hit $50bn. http://www.theglobaleconomy.com/South-Korea/Reserves/. 
This monumental forex burn was to protect their currency. And in the months not represented in the recent ticdata Donald Trump was elected and the dollar has surged. Should the Saudis want to protect their currency, it is possible. However, the East Asian example was a one off and admittedly included all forex, not just dollars. As a result, I will greatly reduce my forecast to 5%

The veto decision is no longer an issue, and there is no economic rationale for the Saudis to sell off the treasuries by that much. Nov holding increased by 7b from Oct despite the general mass sell offs of treasuries due to Trumpflation expectations.

There is an interesting trend in Saudi Arabia's treasury holdings: since January 2016 treasury holdings declined from a peak of $123.7 bn to $ 89.4 bn in September. This means treasuries declined on average by almost $ 4.3 bn per month.  Since movements in U.S. treasury holdings don't seem to be correlated with movements in oil prices, it seems like the Saudi government plans to slowly readjust its asset portfolio.

Downgrading from 34 % due to OPEC oil deal and the fact that if the Saudis didn't already dump most of their holdings, it would make little sense for them to continue to do so in the current yield environment.

Without doing any math to confirm my hypotesis, I would guess that Saudi Arabia treasury holdings are positive correlated with treasury yields and oil prices. Both can increase in the near future, that's why yes in this question seem unlikely.
At the present level of around 90 billion (http://ticdata.treasury.gov/Publish/mfh.txt), it seems a too drastic change.

A period of large global uncertainty follows the US election which may lead to a larger drop in oil prices. The conflict in Yemen also makes the situation more uncertain since larger budgetary allocation may be made for the coming year.

Decrease in US treasuries to below 50 would require decrease of 5.9bn per month until June, far greater than 3.9bn it has decreased since then. Some months have been larger than this (April saw a drop of over $10 billion) but there has been no sustained period in the last 2 years of a sufficiently large outflows. And looking beyond, to the distant past, there has been no year in the last, let alone 7 months, where foreign currency reserves have been depleted by over 50%. The recent increase in oil prices will lead to an increase in government revenue which, coupled with budget cuts, will reduce pressure to take from foreign reserves. Finally, the fear that Saudi Arabia will unload all their US treasuries to punish the US for passing the Justice for Sponsors of Terrorism Act is far overblown. Since it was passed there has been no increase in their burning through the reserves, which should make sense, as doing so would only be shooting themselves in the foot. The only way they would take such drastic measures would be very frayed relations under Trump, which is possible but unlikely in such a short time span. The baseline, given the lack of historical precedent, must be 10%. However, the recent surge in burning through reserves increases the chance significantly, to 20%, and the chance of Trump hostilities an additional 5%. 25% in total

Depending on the time frame the decrease in Saudi holdings of US treasuries is ~$3.9 billion per month (April - September 2016 = 113 - 89.4). Even at this rate  the projected Saudi holdings in May 2017 would be ~$58 billion.  However this range includes the biggest singe dip in holdings between May and April 2016 of $10 billion. I'd be incline to consider the $3.9 rate to be higher than what we'll see till June 2017.  How much the Saudi's will sell will depend partially on the oil price. Looking at Nasdaq oil price data the 10 billion dip in holdings came after a period of a low oil price. Oil prices are currently higher. Conclusion: when the oil prices drop again we may see the Saudi's selling more US treasuries again.

Replying to my first challenge question. Wish me good judgement. I give it below 50% probability, but keeping it close to 50-50 as I've yet to find sufficient data. Few considerations:
- I would expect substantial % of SA foreign reserves to be in USD. Makes sense given the currency peg. SA foreign reserves have been going down but are still orders of magnitude above $50bn.
https://www.imf.org/external/np/sta/ir/IRProcessWeb/data/sau/eng/hstSAU.pdf - Treasury data show a recent decline but over a 1y period there has been up-down swings. I'm not confident on my knowledge of SA's treasury decisions (could be pressures from budget deficit, could be duration management etc, so for the moment expect the range to be between 40 and 110. Also this data reports direct holding by country - SA may well hold some US Treasury through other countries' accounts (i.e. in the UAE)
http://ticdata.treasury.gov/Publish/mfh.txt

There is no big chance that Saudi-Arabian holdings in US securities will dip below 50bn. It would mean a reduction of currrent holdings by more than 40% which is highly unlikely. Only major shifts in attractiveness or foreign policy impacts with the US would reduce the figure thus far.

The mass sell-off of US treasuries in the wake of the Trump presidency and higher inflation expectations will certainly cause a dip in the Saudi holdings, but whether they will decrease almost 50 % remains to be seen. The data is a snapshot of the holdings at the end of the reference month, so its possible they dip below 50 billion without being reflected in the figures. US treasuries remain the benchmark safe asset so its unlikely countries will sell off their holding entirely and there will probably be regulations against doing that (i.e. requiring to hold a certain amount safe assets).
Its seems an interesting Subject to follow

SA holdings have dropped 30b since January. At that rate it would not reach 50b by June 2017. They could accelerate that or they may find other ways to punish the US. Waiting to see what a Trump administrations relationship with SA will be and if that will impact our congress.

@Raahul_Kumar - thanks for the pointer to official treasury data. Few things stand out:
- Holdings increased before they started decreasing in January this year. This could indicate cyclicality. I haven't tried to get 2 or 5 year data, but if that's available, it would give us a more accurate view into holding patterns over time.
- The rate of decrease is significantly more when you consider the most recent data. I still arrive at about $80B reservers using this formula: =123.7-((123.7-93)/7)*10 where
123.7 is Jan holdings
93 is Aug holdings
7 is number of months from Jan to Aug
10 is number of months from Aug to Jun 2017
- Decrease generally corresponds to a severe dip in oil prices: http://www.macrotrends.net/1369/crude-oil-price-history-chart starting Oct 2015. Oil prices have since recovered and we do see a pattern of slower selling in the last 3 months of available data. I am not significantly changing my forecast but do feel that I need to increase the probability a bit given the rate of selling is higher than I earlier calculated. Folks - I encourage you to poke holes in this logic if you see them and/or add you reasoning / data.

But these threats could be empty, since it will greatly impact them as well, and with oil revenues down, their economy is already (relatively) more fragile currently. Saudi holdings of US treasuries is likely to decline but not so much that they get down below $50B by June 1st.
Trump's energy and wars in Saudi's realm may help to reduce holdings

As of August 2016, Saudi Arabia had about USD$93.0 billion in Treasury Securities. While this number has been falling over the past year (in Aug 2015, it was 113.0 billion), the pace of the fall appears be responding to changes in crude oil prices, since crude oil makes up 77 - 88% of Saudi's total income. That said, the recent stability of crude oil prices  could help to stabilise the macroeconomic outlook for Saudi Arabia. On the other hand, Saudi's central bank reserves have fallen dramatically in order to sustain the riyal, while its fiscal deficit appears to be unsustainable going forward. However, with interest rates low in advanced economies financial markets eager for yield, Saudi Arabia should be able to maintain its current reserves until 1 June 2017. This is of course under the assumptions that Saudi's government undertake structural reforms that signify clear to the financial markets that they are diversifying their economy through the relaxation of trade barriers and easing the cost of doing business. Sources: 
http://ticdata.treasury.gov/Publish/mfh.txt
https://www.brookings.edu/opinions/saudi-arabias-economic-time-bomb/

In May 2016 report, they held $117B. In October 2016 report, they held $93B. At $4.8B decrease per month, it comes pretty darn close to $50B reserve mark. The decrease may put pressure on listing shares in Aramco. It may also push Saudis to use more debt instruments to cover the imbalance and bridge to Aramco listing. I'm thinking that they will want to preserve the reserve mark ...$50B is a nice round number to protect.

At this point, we do not know the full amount of the Kingdom reserves. Bloomberg news speculates, the Kingdom might hold up to half trillion dollars, with a $300Billion forecast in the low end. the Saudi government said to fill the present budget the Saudi government is going to need another $90 Billion at present oil prices, so I do not see getting reserves below $50 billion.
